RT @Michelle4Laughs: I'm beyond thrilled to welcome my newest client to @StormLiterary!  @HollyN_Jennings' story channels Fury Road and The…
Thank you to everyone who ever bought my books, beta read, swapped stories, retweeted me, left a review, or pushed me onward when I wanted to give up. I love all of you.

If I sound like I'm bragging, I am. I'm so damn proud to have made it to this point, and I'm very thankful to those of you who have been with me since the beginning, whether that's since Arena's first release (cough, @Glenn_sccc) or since I started writing (cough, @thejasonrush)
I wrote thousands of words and received hundreds of rejections, trunked a 160K novel that went nowhere, all through the pandemic and my personal health struggles.
This has been three long years in the making, ever since my former agent left the business to pursue other dreams and kick ass in another industry. (You're amazing, @LeonHusock.)

I'm so excited to announce I'm now represented by @Michelle4Laughs at @StormLiterary. Michelle is truly the right champion for my sci-fi western mashup and everything else going forward. Can't wait to start this journey with all of you!

Received a few more rejections this week, but two were beautifully personalized. They emphasized that the writing quality was strong — they just weren't the right agent for the work.

It really feels like this story is just a matter of finding the right person to champion it.

Last week: 4 agent requests on Project Havoc.

Today: 3 query rejections in 4 hours.

As the MC in the book would say: This has been one helluva ride.

Take care of yourselves and each other.

4. Consider putting a sign on your door if you have regular deliveries. Despite indicating on the delivery instructions that I was sick, several people wanted me to open the door -- until I yelled through it that I had Covid.

2. Get more cough and pain medicine than you think you'll need. I ran out twice.

3. If you think you're getting better after a few days, you might still nosedive back down. Don't overdo it just because you start to feel well again.

I think I'm recovered from Covid now and wanted to post a few tips if any of you have to deal with it. This is not medical advice, of course.

1. Have a thermometer and oximeter on hand -- especially the oximeter. It can give you peace of mind if you start to get out of breath.

My PCP has switched me to crutches and using my leg as little as possible. It looks like there might be a hairline crack in my femur that wasn't there in the October CT scan.

So that means lots of writing time and gaming time on the couch. Oh, darn.

I have the MRI results from my PCP. I either have a bone disease called fibrous dysplasia or a benign tumor called a lipsoclerosing myxofibrous. 

Both are non-life-threatening and treatable, but also very rare. Finding a specialist with experience might be tough.
@monicazahariev I appreciate that. I’m just happy to know it’s Something. For a while, I felt like my body was just overreacting for no reason. 😆
@monicazahariev Yes. Since August 2020, we’ve known there was a problem somewhere in the lower right quadrant, but not the hip itself. We’ve finally pinpointed the location, but not what it is yet.
My enemy finally has a face but still no name. https://t.co/Mog0CdloOu

@Glenn_sccc The claustrophobia wasn't as bad as I expected. My head was half-out of the machine for most of the testing. 

The first several minutes were hard, but I relaxed after that.
Also, The music didn’t work for most of the scan and I heard all the weird robotic noises, so I just pretended I was murderbot. https://t.co/bjwJaoiPN5
MRI is done. Not a fun experience, but it's over. Thanks to everyone for the well wishes!

Now is the question of whether I actually find this room IRL even with a physical map and clear instructions. It certainly never helped in WoW.

TLDR: Publishing is a slow process, but I've had a bit of luck so far with the contests and a full request.

Moving forward: sending more queries and MAYBE another contest (it tends to be the same agents in the contests, so after a few, it might not be worth the effort/time.)
According to https://t.co/3eLAsiWd4O, many writers have heard responses long after I've sent my email in. This leads me to wonder if I'm perpetually trapped in some agents' "maybe" piles.

* Rejections are what you think: An agent declined to read further and is not interested in the book.

The most interesting part of the process this time (I've queried and landed an agent when I first wrote Arena) is the lack of response from queries sent months ago. However...

* A full request means an agent read the sample pages and asked to see the entire manuscript

* Queries are a specialized email that include a summary of the book and (sometimes) sample pages to try to entice an agent into wanting the entire manuscript

Breaking down some of the terminology for those who might not be familiar…

* A request from a contest usually means an agent is intrigued by my book's concept and wants to see sample pages to preview my writing style

Since I'm aiming for transparency with all of you in my quest to find my new book a home, I'm posting some stats of where we're at right now…

Requests from contests: 3
Full requests: 1 
Queries sent (outside of contests): 6
Rejections: 2
🚨Update on this: an agent came in with a late request!🚨 https://t.co/6JWOGY7Iuk

@diminish7 Agreed. I foresaw this problem with plotting and have created an "MC agency list" to document all the times the protagonist makes a decision that is not simply dictated by the plot. I think it's helping, but it's definitely something to keep in mind when I'm writing.
But plotting the book ahead of time has helped me spot the areas lacking tension/conflict so I can correct them right away instead of having to rework/rewrite entire scenes. So far, I'm liking this.
Plotting vs. planning: I'm learning that it's much easier for me to plan out the plot than the characters. I'm so used to getting to know these people through actual writing.

So, anyways. I know this has nothing to do with books or writing, but I'm just so dang excited and proud of this accomplishment that I had to share. 

On to the next goal!

I never took pictures because I was embarrassed of how skinny I was (now I wish I would have!) but my body went from:

30-24-32 
to 
34-25-37 (hello hips!)

So I did, and they were right. I couldn't out-eat my metabolism, but I could out-drink it and out-lift it

What surprises me the most is the difference in my strength. I went from barely picking up my dog's 30lb bag of food to picking my grandma off the floor when she had a fall

When you don't have this body, you don't understand what it needs. Neither did I. My breakthrough was when I finally looked up vlogs of girls with the same problem as me. Their advice was all the same: drink mass-gaining shakes and lift heavy at the gym.

I tried a bunch of things that failed. Well-meaning people gave me advice that mostly consisted of "just eat something." But after days of eating more, I'd end up with heartburn and indigestion and would slide back down the scale.

For all of my life, I was underweight. I had a tiny appetite and a fast metabolism (yes, I was That Bitch). Doctors kept telling me not to worry about it. I would put weight on "eventually."

By 33, I was done waiting for "eventually."

Weight gain complete!

The scale in June 2018 vs October 2019

This book is new and completely different from the Arena series.

Regardless if anyone likes it or whether it gets picked up by a publisher, I've discovered the type of books I want to write. I want to thank all of you for being patient with me while I figured this out over the last few years and I hope I get to share new stories with you soon.

At this point, it will be done by the end of the year, if not sooner. I'm constantly wavering between "I'm so proud of this" and "no one will want to read this crap." Impostor syndrome never really goes away for an author.

I've explored other book ideas over the last two years, but none spoke to me like this one. It's the book I've always wanted to write, because it's the book I've always wanted to read but could never find on the shelf.
I've been fairly quiet on social media lately because I've been working hard to finish my new book. It'll be the first novel I've finished since Gauntlet nearly two years ago.

@Glenn_sccc Yes! It may be easier to divide subgenres into book examples instead of bullet point qualifiers. And you've got something there... most fantasies (regardless of the subgenre) contain eurocentric standard tropes.

@Glenn_sccc Why decide? As an author, it's important to know where your book fits. You don't want to promise people one thing and deliver something else entirely. Plus, I'm also curious about how/if people divide up the subgenres of fantasy. There seems to be a lot of crossover between them.

I've always considered them different, divided by "scale."

Epic fantasy - realm-threatening consequences, massive wars, plot/travel involving multiple continents. 

High fantasy - still second-world setting but more of a focus on characters, magic, and/or politics.
Question time: in your opinion, are high fantasy and epic fantasy different subgenres or the same/interchangeable?

So the question becomes: What would those characters of power choose to do in that kind of world? Would they still work toward it, or away from it? Or would they carry it as a burden, knowing they are the lesser evil to possess said power?

And drops them into a world where the more power you have, the more likely you are to fail, be killed, or become the villain. In other words, the more special you are, the more screwed you might be. Possessing power starts off as wish fulfillment and quickly becomes anything but.

This is what I love about New Book. It subverts this trope, but in a different way. It takes stock fantasy characters of innate power -- one with a powerful birthright, one with a powerful bloodline, and one with a powerful ability… https://t.co/pe8nQJqlRt

Discipline to keep going, year after year, even when things don't work out the way you expected and no one else sees your vision. You don't have to be the most talented writer in the world. You just have to be the hardest working one.

Becoming an author is more about self-discipline than talent. Discipline to write even when you're running on only 3 hours of sleep. Discipline not to lash out at rejections or criticism, and instead use them to become better.

Great piece of advice someone gave me: write your ideal review of your WIP and use it as motivation. It'll help you focus on what you're trying to achieve and what matters most to you in the book.

So to all the writers who are struggling after their first book deal: you've already proven yourself. Take the time to figure out who you really are instead of what publishing wants. What's in your heart is more important than what's selling in the industry. We need your passion.

Most of the time, I realize the answer is "no." Sometimes it takes just a basic outline to realize this, sometimes it takes thousands of words written. None of it is time wasted. I'm learning about myself as a writer and as a human.

"Do I want to talk about these topics on panels in front of hundreds of people? Do I think I have something new to add to this important theme?" These are the questions I'm learning to ask myself now when I'm working on a new idea.

While exploring different story ideas, it's easy to get caught up in the "will this sell to publishers?" or "will this appeal to the market?" mindset instead of "do I want to spend the next 2-5 years of my life with this story?"

For a while, I felt guilty about this. So many people would say to me, "But you're good at writing the YA voice and tropes!" and "Not everyone can write for teens and that's where the money is!" And for a while, I listened to them. Sometimes I still do.

Still, there were things I didn't love about Arena. I'm not big on romance tropes. I much prefer adult voices over YA (I know, I’M SORRY). I like stories that carry me away to a different planet, universe or realm where I can forget about the perils of humanity.

Luckily, there were things I really loved about Arena. I love video games. I LOVE Kali & the gang, especially since they represented a diverse group of gamers. I have immense respect for pro gamers and believe they don't get the recognition they deserve from mainstream media.

The topic and themes discussed in your book will dictate what magazines and blogs interview you, what panels you'll be placed on, and what you'll be talking about every day for years to come. I didn't know this as a debut. I know better now.

Writing this next book is about "what do I love?" Now that I have two books, a handful of conventions, and an award under my belt, I've come to realize that writing a book isn't just about the book. It's about the next 2-5 years of your life, if not more.

Starting a new book/series after being previously published is very different than writing your debut. Writing Arena was about "Can I get there?" Can I get an agent? Can I get a book deal? It was about proving myself.

Again, this isn't for everyone but it's something I've found highly effective for me.
By the end of the day, you could have both your writing and household chores complete and at a more efficient rate.
So, moving around on your writing breaks is a GOOD THING. Use that time to get things done that get you off your butt.

Even more, studies have shown that walking around (even inside the house) helps inspire creativity.
https://t.co/A74mZbiuTy
Plus, cleaning and doing household chores on your "15 min off" helps relieve the guilt of spending time on writing.
You can always write longer if you're on a breakaway, but it also stops you from stewing too long if the words aren't flowing.
Breaking writing sessions down into 15 mins creates a sense of urgency. How much can I get done in 15?

Like so, 

1:00 PM: Write
1:15 PM: Wash Dishes
1:30 PM: Write
1:45 PM: Do laundry
2:00 PM: Write

And so on.
Write in blocks of 15, 20, or 30 minutes. Try different chunks of time and see what works for you. I use 15 min on/ 15 min off.
It's highly effective if you're someone who drifts easily, needs to move often, or gets intimated by writing for hours.
Try "time blocking." It won't work for everyone. Probably won't work for most. But some of you may find this is for you.
Another #writingtip. This goes out to all the people who, like me, have a hard time staying focused during writing sessions.

So tldr: don't over-describe the fight. Balance the fight between action, reaction, and sensory detail, with an emphasis on the last two.
Lastly, setting should only be described as it comes into the fight. Don't tell me the ground is muddy unless your character lands in it.
Notice how much stronger this is compared to: "he punched my jaw and my cheek split open."
"Something hard slammed my jaw. Bones crunched. My vision reeled. A metallic taste filled my mouth and burned the back of my throat."
Another great way to convey the action in a fight is to tell it through sensory detail. This, again, puts you into the character's POV.
But once you describe the hit, focus on how your character reacts. This is what makes the fight HUMAN and REAL.
And when you do describe the action, power verbs go a long way. Instead of "His fist connected with my jaw," try "His fist crushed my jaw."
Reactions are more important than actions and there are many in fights: Panic, fear, rage, triumph, confusion, shock, regret, disbelief, etc
Fights should be a mix of action and reaction. Create natural "breakaways" so you can delve into the character's thoughts.
How your character reacts to a fight shows a lot about their character. Do they run, stand their ground, get excited, go cold?
I'm not saying, don't describe the fight at all. I'm saying, get inside your character's head. What are they thinking?
If you're in a fight, your thought isn't: "he's reeling back to deliver a left jab to my right cheek." Your thought is: "move" or "f$@K!"
This makes the fight feel unrealistic and mechanical. Fights should be visceral, emotional, and full of sensory detail.
The biggest mistake I see in fight scenes is the author trying to describe every punch, kick, and blow with precise detail.
Okay, #writingtip time. I get asked a lot how I write fight scenes. 1st of all, thanks. 2nd, I still struggle but here's my advice.

@TheSol23 I understood the first half of this tweet, but not the second half. :) #QKChat
@lexicalcreation @LidsRodney I agree with this. Sometimes they'll give you feedback to will help land the right one #QKChat
Did anyone's question get missed entirely? The feed got a little crazy. #QKChat
@alexisdaria Technical point: single/double spacing makes a difference in # of pages so I go by word count. 500ish has worked for me #qkchat
@Michelle4Laughs Try to stick to the big ideas, and leave the rest on the table. Like a query, it doesn't have to include all #QKChat
@Michelle4Laughs I find them easier to write when I'm in the earlier stages of a book. It's easier to leave out subplots/details. #QKChat
@lexicalcreation Example: MCs who are black AND disabled, Buddhist AND gay, instead of representing just one kind of diversity #QKChat
@lexicalcreation Also, I know you said 'beyond diversity', but I'd like to see this pushed further. More intersectionality. #QKChat
@lexicalcreation Especially female mentors & teachers passing on their skills to younger girls. #qkchat
@lexicalcreation Wow. Great question. I'd like to see more positive female relationships, where they're not "frenemies."
@LidsRodney @JMCDillard However, if one is *really* weak (ex: great query, bad 250), it might end up on the chopping block. #QKChat
@LidsRodney @JMCDillard I'm the same on this one (equal). Sometimes one is a bit weak, but the other pushes the entry ahead.
@Michelle4Laughs I think the number of revisions I did on my Arena query for #querykombat was about the same. 30ish. #QKChat
The only things that are certain about publishing: it's subjective, and you will get rejections. But you only "fail" if you quit. #QKChat
I've read queries/books that I thought wouldn't get published. They did. I've also read ones that I thought would, and they didn't. #QKChat
Sometimes, the person who will love your book just wasn't in that particular contest. Dust yourself off, and keep going. #qkchat
This is one of the most important things I've learned. If you don't get in, it doesn't mean you've written a bad book. #QKChat
It's important to remember that contests, like publishing, are very subjective. What you like, others might not. And vice versa. #QKChat
